qas.question: When did The Impact Team successfully breach Ashley Madison?
What is the name of the parent company that created Ashley Madison?
When did the Avid Life Media CEO resign?
What was in the first data dump?
What website, in addition to Ashley Madison, was Avid Media instructed to take offline?

plausible_answers.text: they had taken not only company data but user data as well.

qas.question: Why was the website to be removed?
How did the site remain functional after the data breach?

plausible_answers.text: release all customer records, including profiles with all the customers' secret sexual fantasies and matching credit card transactions, real names and addresses

qas.question: What was the response from people using the service?
Was the Goal of the Impact Team carried out?

plausible_answers.text: Ashley Madison and Established Men offline permanently in all forms

qas.question: Were other sites compromised in addition to Ashley Madison?
Who was the CEO of Ashley Madison?
When was Ashley Madison taken down?
When was Established Man taken offline?
How large was the data dump of the CEO's emails?
Why was the customer data dumped first?

context: In <a0_0><b11_0>July of 2015<b11_0/><a0_0/>, a hacker group known as "The Impact Team" successfully breached the extramarital relationship website Ashley Madison. The group claimed that <b5_0>they had taken not only company data but user data as well.<b5_0/> After the breach, The Impact Team dumped <a3_0>emails from the company's CEO<a3_0/>, <b14_0>to prove their point<b14_0/>, and threatened to dump customer data unless the website was taken down permanently. With this initial data release, the group stated “Avid Life Media has been instructed to take <b9_0>Ashley Madison and <a4_0>Established Men<a4_0/> offline permanently in all forms<b9_0/>, or we will <b7_0>release all customer records, including profiles with all the customers' secret sexual fantasies and matching credit card transactions, real names and addresses<b7_0/>, and employee documents and emails. The other websites may stay online.”  When <a1_0>Avid Life Media<a1_0/>, the parent company that created the Ashley Madison website, did not take the site offline, The Impact Group released two more compressed files, one <b13_0>9.7GB<b13_0/> and the second 20GB. <a2_0><b12_0>After the second data dump<b12_0/><a2_0/>, Avid Life Media <b6_0>CEO <b10_0>Noel Biderman<b10_0/> resigned<b6_0/>, but <b8_0>the website remained functional<b8_0/>.
